metadata.titleEn: Distribution map of the relationship between vegetation and freeze-thaw changes in the Arctic (1982-2015)
metadata.description: As an important part of the global carbon pool, Arctic permafrost is one of the most sensitive regions to global climate change. The rate of warming in the Arctic is twice the global average, causing rapid changes in Arctic permafrost. The NDVI change data set of different types of permafrost regions in the Northern Hemisphere from 1982 to 2015 has a temporal resolution of every five years, covers the entire Arctic Rim countries, and a spatial resolution of 8km. Based on multi-source remote sensing, simulation, statistics and measured data, GIS method and ecological method are used to quantify the regulation and service function of permafrost in the northern hemisphere to the ecosystem, and all the data are subject to quality control.
metadata.instructions: The distribution map of the relationship between vegetation and freeze-thaw changes in the Arctic region is stored in the format of maps and can be opened by ArcGIS.

background: Permafrost is a subsurface phenomenon that underlies a significant part of the land and sea in the Northern Hemisphere. Permafrost stores large amounts of organic carbon, affects the stability of bedrock and unconsolidated sediments, and impacts the costs and methods used for infrastructure development. Despite its global significance, there is still no method to reliably detect the occurrence and extent of permafrost at medium to high spatial resolutions and at a global scale. The first comprehensive Northern Hemisphere permafrost extent map was compiled by Brown et al. (1997), based on national and regional maps and expert knowledge from different time periods and sources. High-resolution maps (up to 1km2) have been successfully produced using the TTOP (temperature at the top of permafrost) model for individual regions and countries. The TTOP approach uses only a small number of input parameters and has been successfully employed at regional and continental scales for Canada, Scandinavia, and China.
research objective: In this study, we extend and improve the remote sensing approach of Westermann et al. (2015a) and apply a TTOP–based scheme to the entire Northern Hemisphere. We compile the first permafrost temperature and zonation map at the circum-Arctic scale with a resolution of 1km2 that includes a statistical representation of subpixel variability of permafrost temperatures based on snow and landcover heterogeneity.
challenges: Despite its global significance, there is still no method to reliably detect the occurrence and extent of permafrost at medium to high spatial resolutions and at a global scale. Extrapolating these observations to larger regions is hampered by the considerable spatial variability of the ground thermal regime and an uneven distribution of sites that results in extensive unsampled areas.
methods: For calculation of mean annual ground temperature (MAGT), we use the CryoGrid 1 model, based on the TTOP equilibrium approach. We compile spatially distributed datasets of TDD and FDD from remotely sensed land surface temperature (LST) products. We employ the MODIS MOD11A1 and MYD11A1 level 3 product in processing version 6, which contains up to two daytime and two night-time measurements per day. Downscaling of the ERA-interim reanalysis data to the 1km2 resolution of individual MODIS pixels is accomplished by computing atmospheric lapse rates and the elevation difference between the ERA orography field and the elevation of a 1km2 pixel. We compare our ensemble MAGT mean to in-situ point measurements in 359 boreholes in the GTN-P and 392 boreholes in the TSP project network. The model calculates mean annual ground temperature (MAGT) at the top of the permafrost based on mean annual air temperature (MAAT) and uses semi-empirical adjustment factors for the effects of snow cover and the thermal offset.
dataset: We compile spatially distributed datasets of TDD and FDD from remotely sensed land surface temperature (LST) products. The Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometers (MODIS) on board the Terra and Aqua satellites have provided LST measurements at a spatial resolution of 1km2 since 2000 and 2002, respectively. The study period, therefore, starts in 2000 and extends to the end of 2016. Extended data gaps in the MODIS LST time series due to cloud cover can result in a systematic cold bias in seasonal averages.
findings: The accuracy of the modelled mean annual ground temperature (MAGT) at the top of the permafrost is ±2°C when compared to permafrost borehole data. The modelled permafrost area (MAGT<0°C) covers 13.9×106 km2 (ca. 15% of the exposed land area), which is within the range or slightly below the average of previous estimates. The sum of all pixels having isolated patches, sporadic, discontinuous or continuous permafrost (permafrost probability>0) is around 21×106 km2 (22% of exposed land area), which is approximately 2×106 km2 less than estimated previously.

Example.Question: Can you give an example of a data collection method for assessing permafrost temperature and zonation at a high spatial resolution?
Example.Answer: An example of a data collection method is the use of the CryoGrid 1 model based on the TTOP equilibrium approach, which involves compiling spatially distributed datasets of TDD (thawing degree days) and FDD (freezing degree days) from remotely sensed land surface temperature (LST) products provided by the MODIS MOD11A1 and MYD11A1 level 3 products.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced when compiling datasets for permafrost extent and temperature at a global scale?
Example.Answer: An example of a challenge is the considerable spatial variability of the ground thermal regime and the uneven distribution of sites, which results in extensive unsampled areas, making it difficult to reliably detect the occurrence and extent of permafrost at medium to high spatial resolutions globally.

Example.Question: Could you provide an example of a dataset that aids in understanding the spatial variability of permafrost temperatures?
Example.Answer: An example of such a dataset includes spatially distributed datasets of TDD and FDD derived from remotely sensed LST products, specifically the MODIS measurements, which have been available at a spatial resolution of 1km2 since 2000 and 2002, respectively.

Definition.Question: What is the 'TTOP equilibrium approach' in the context of permafrost temperature modeling?
Definition.Answer: The TTOP equilibrium approach is a method used to calculate mean annual ground temperature (MAGT) at the top of the permafrost. It is based on mean annual air temperature (MAAT) and uses semi-empirical adjustment factors for the effects of snow cover and the thermal offset.

Definition.Question: What is meant by 'subpixel variability of permafrost temperatures' in remote sensing?
Definition.Answer: Subpixel variability of permafrost temperatures refers to the statistical representation of temperature variations within a pixel, which can be affected by factors such as snow and landcover heterogeneity. This concept is used to enhance the accuracy of permafrost temperature mapping at high resolutions.

Comparison.Question: How does the use of GIS methods and ecological approaches in quantifying permafrost's ecosystem regulatory functions compare to the TTOP-based scheme for mapping permafrost temperature and zonation?
Comparison.Answer: The GIS methods and ecological approaches are used to quantify the regulatory functions of permafrost on ecosystems, relying on multi-source data and focusing on the ecological impact of permafrost. In contrast, the TTOP-based scheme is centered on mapping permafrost temperature and zonation, utilizing remote sensing data and statistical methods to achieve high-resolution permafrost temperature mapping.

Comparison.Question: In what ways do the challenges of detecting permafrost occurrence and extent at medium to high spatial resolutions differ from the issues encountered with data gaps in MODIS LST time series?
Comparison.Answer: The challenge of detecting permafrost involves the considerable spatial variability of the ground thermal regime and the uneven distribution of observation sites, leading to unsampled areas at medium to high resolutions. On the other hand, the MODIS LST time series faces challenges due to data gaps caused by cloud cover, which can lead to systematic biases in the temperature data.

Interpretation.Question: How can the variability in snow and landcover heterogeneity influence the accuracy of remotely sensed permafrost temperature data?
Interpretation.Answer: The variability in snow and landcover heterogeneity is statistically represented in the permafrost temperature and zonation map at the circum-Arctic scale, which allows for subpixel variability of permafrost temperatures. This variability can influence the accuracy of remotely sensed data by affecting the thermal regime and introducing spatial variability that must be accounted for in modeling permafrost temperatures.

Interpretation.Question: What are the challenges in using remote sensing data for detecting the extent of permafrost at medium to high spatial resolutions?
Interpretation.Answer: The challenges in using remote sensing data include the considerable spatial variability of the ground thermal regime and the uneven distribution of observation sites, which results in extensive unsampled areas. Additionally, extended data gaps due to cloud cover in MODIS LST time series can result in systematic cold biases in seasonal averages, complicating the reliable detection of permafrost extent.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes challenges in detecting the occurrence and extent of permafrost at medium to high spatial resolutions globally?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The significant spatial variability of the ground thermal regime and an uneven distribution of observational sites contribute to challenges in reliably detecting permafrost occurrence and extent at medium to high spatial resolutions globally, resulting in extensive unsampled areas.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it difficult to extrapolate permafrost observations to larger regions?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Extrapolating permafrost observations to larger regions is difficult due to considerable spatial variability in the ground thermal regime and the uneven distribution of observation sites, which leads to extensive unsampled areas.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors lead to systematic cold bias in MODIS LST time series used for permafrost data collection?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Extended data gaps in the MODIS LST time series, often due to cloud cover, can lead to a systematic cold bias in seasonal averages when used for permafrost data collection.

Causal Consequence.Question: How might the application of GIS methods influence the quantification of ecosystem regulatory services in permafrost regions?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The application of GIS methods in quantifying ecosystem regulatory services in permafrost regions allows for spatial analysis and visualization of data. It can enhance the understanding of permafrost's impact on ecosystems by incorporating diverse datasets, such as temperature and vegetation indices, thereby providing a detailed spatial distribution of ecological functions and changes over time.

Causal Consequence.Question: What could be the impact on data accuracy when using remotely sensed land surface temperature products with extended data gaps due to cloud cover?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using remotely sensed land surface temperature products with extended data gaps due to cloud cover can introduce a systematic cold bias in seasonal averages. This could affect the accuracy of modelled ground temperatures, potentially leading to underestimation of permafrost areas and challenges in accurately assessing permafrost dynamics and trends.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to develop a permafrost temperature and zonation map at the circum-Arctic scale using a TTOP-based scheme?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Developing a permafrost temperature and zonation map at the circum-Arctic scale using a TTOP-based scheme is important because it helps overcome the challenges of detecting permafrost occurrence and extent at medium to high spatial resolutions globally. This map provides a comprehensive understanding of permafrost conditions, accommodating the considerable spatial variability and uneven site distribution, thus improving infrastructure planning and climate change impact assessments in these regions.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the goal of using MODIS LST data in conjunction with atmospheric lapse rates and elevation differences for downscaling ERA-interim reanalysis data?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goal of using MODIS LST data with atmospheric lapse rates and elevation differences for downscaling ERA-interim reanalysis data is to achieve a higher resolution of 1km2 for individual MODIS pixels. This method enhances the accuracy of permafrost temperature modeling and provides better spatial representation of ground thermal regimes, which are crucial for validating model outputs against in-situ borehole measurements and refining regional and continental permafrost mapping.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How do researchers address the challenges of cloud cover affecting the accuracy of MODIS LST data in the analysis of permafrost temperature and zonation?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Extended data gaps in the MODIS LST time series due to cloud cover can result in a systematic cold bias in seasonal averages. Researchers must account for these gaps and biases when analyzing permafrost temperature and zonation, possibly through data interpolation or using complementary data sources to fill in the missing information.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedure is followed in using the CryoGrid 1 model to calculate mean annual ground temperature (MAGT) at the top of permafrost?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The CryoGrid 1 model calculates MAGT at the top of permafrost based on the TTOP equilibrium approach. It uses mean annual air temperature (MAAT) and semi-empirical adjustment factors for the effects of snow cover and thermal offset. The model's results are compared against in-situ point measurements from boreholes to verify accuracy.

Enablement.Question: How do statistical methods enable the representation of subpixel variability in permafrost temperature mapping?
Enablement.Answer: Statistical methods enable the representation of subpixel variability in permafrost temperature mapping by accounting for heterogeneity in snow cover and landcover, which influence permafrost temperatures. These methods allow for a more detailed representation of temperature variations within a pixel, thereby improving the accuracy of permafrost zonation maps.

Enablement.Question: What conditions or factors influence the accuracy of modeled mean annual ground temperatures in permafrost regions?
Enablement.Answer: The accuracy of modeled mean annual ground temperatures in permafrost regions is influenced by factors such as the quality and resolution of land surface temperature data, the modeling approach used (e.g., TTOP equilibrium approach), and the consideration of snow cover effects and thermal offsets. Additionally, the presence of data gaps due to cloud cover in remotely sensed time series can also affect the accuracy of seasonal temperature averages.

Expectation.Question: Why might there be difficulties in using remote sensing technology to map permafrost extent at a medium to high spatial resolution?
Expectation.Answer: Despite the global significance of permafrost, reliably detecting its occurrence and extent at medium to high spatial resolutions is challenging due to the considerable spatial variability of the ground thermal regime and an uneven distribution of sites, which results in extensive unsampled areas.

Expectation.Question: What are potential reasons for the systematic cold bias in seasonal averages of remotely sensed land surface temperature datasets?
Expectation.Answer: Extended data gaps in the MODIS LST time series due to cloud cover can result in a systematic cold bias in seasonal averages.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, what are the main challenges associated with detecting permafrost occurrence and extent using current data collection methods?
Judgmental.Answer: The main challenges include the considerable spatial variability of the ground thermal regime, which complicates extrapolation to larger regions, and the uneven distribution of observation sites leading to unsampled areas. Additionally, there is no universally reliable method to detect permafrost at medium to high spatial resolutions globally, which affects the accuracy and comprehensiveness of the data collected.

Judgmental.Question: What are the potential advantages and limitations of integrating multiple data sources, such as remote sensing, simulations, and in-situ measurements, in studying permafrost dynamics?
Judgmental.Answer: Integrating multiple data sources allows for a more comprehensive analysis of permafrost dynamics by combining the strengths of each method, such as the wide coverage of remote sensing and the detailed accuracy of in-situ measurements. However, limitations include potential discrepancies between data sources and the complexity of merging datasets with varying resolutions and scales. Despite these challenges, such integration enhances the understanding of permafrost distribution and temperature.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how spatial variability in permafrost temperatures can be accurately represented using remote sensing data.
Assertion.Answer: The spatial variability of permafrost temperatures is represented statistically by using snow and landcover heterogeneity. The TTOP–based scheme is applied to compile a permafrost temperature and zonation map with a resolution of 1km2, which includes this variability.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how data from different sources like remote sensing, simulations, and statistical measurements are integrated to study permafrost changes.
Assertion.Answer: Data from multiple sources such as remote sensing, simulations, and statistical measurements are integrated using GIS and ecological methods, ensuring that all datasets undergo quality control. This integration allows for the quantification of the permafrost's ecological regulatory service functions.

Assertion.Question: I am unsure about the challenges faced in detecting permafrost extent and its implications for data collection.
Assertion.Answer: Detecting the extent of permafrost at medium to high spatial resolutions globally is challenging due to the considerable spatial variability of the ground thermal regime and uneven distribution of sampling sites, leading to extensive unsampled areas.

Request/Directive.Question: Please summarize the challenges encountered in detecting the occurrence and extent of permafrost at medium to high spatial resolutions on a global scale and suggest potential solutions.
Request/Directive.Answer: Challenges include the considerable spatial variability of the ground thermal regime and uneven distribution of observation sites, resulting in extensive unsampled areas. Potential solutions could involve improving remote sensing techniques and enhancing model accuracy by incorporating more comprehensive datasets and finer spatial resolutions.
